revision.text:
{{No footnotes|date=April 2011}}
'''Cryogenic deflashing''' is a [[deflashing]] process that uses [[cryogenic]] temperatures to aid in the removal of [[flash (manufacturing)|flash]] on [[casting|cast]] or [[molding (process)|molded]] workpieces. These temperatures cause the flash to become stiff or brittle and to break away cleanly. Cryogenic deflashing is the preferred process when removing excess material from oddly shaped, custom molded products. ==Process== Parts are loaded into a parts basket. A cryogen, such as [[liquid nitrogen]], is used to cool the workpieces; once cooled they are [[Tumble finishing|tumbled]] and [[media blasting|blasted]] with media pellets, ranging size from {{convert|0.006|to|0.080|in}}. In some instances, cryogenic deflashing does not utilize a blasting action, relying instead only on the tumbling of the parts to remove flash on the outer edges.
==Advantages== Cryogenic deflashing provides various advantages over manual deflashing and other traditional deflashing methods. * The process maintains part integrity and critical tolerances. * Since it is a batch process, the price per piece is far less as many more parts can be processed in a given amount of time. * Cryogenic deflashing extends mold life. Rather than replace or repair a mold (which typically involves downtime and high cost), the parts can be deflashed. This is typical of parts molded at the end of their [[product lifetime]]. * The process is computer controlled, therefore removing the human operator variable from the process. * The process offers consistent results from lot to lot. * Cryogenic deflashing is non-abrasive. * The cost per part is generally well below any alternative technique.
==Applications== A wide range of molded materials can utilize cryogenic deflashing with proven results. These include: * [[Silicone]]s * [[Plastic]]s – (both thermoset & thermoplastic) * [[Rubber]]s – (including neoprene & urethane) * [[Liquid crystal polymer]] (LCP) * Glass-filled nylons * Aluminum zinc die cast
Examples of applications that use cryogenic deflashing include: * [[O-ring]]s & [[gasket]]s * Catheters and other in-vitro medical * Insulators and other electric / electronic * Valve stems, washers and fittings * Tubes and flexible boots * Face masks & goggles
Today, many molding operations are using cryogenic deflashing instead of rebuilding or repairing molds on products that are approaching their [[End-of-life (product)|end-of-life]]. It is often more prudent and economical to add a few cents of production cost for a part than invest in a new molding tool that can cost hundreds of thousands of dollars and has a limited service life due to declining production forecasts.
In other cases, cryogenic deflashing has proven to be an enabling technology, permitting the economical manufacture of high quality, high precision parts fabricated with cutting edge materials and compounds.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.nitrofreeze.com/services/deflashing Nitrofreeze: In-depth information about how cryogenic deflashing works] * [http://www.pfonline.com/articles/a-cool-technology A Cool Technology: Products Finishing Magazine, Matt Little; 4/1/2005]
{{Iron and steel production}}

revision.text:
[[File:Fluidized Bed Concentrator (FBC) at Honda Alabama.png|thumb|A Fluidized Bed Concentrator for VOC control at [[Honda Manufacturing of Alabama]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hondaalabama.com/article/hma-honored-as-air-conservationist-of-the-year|title=Honda Manufacturing Alabama Honored As Air Conservationist of the Year|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref>]]
A '''fluidized bed concentrator''' ('''FBC''') is an industrial process for the treatment of exhaust air. The system uses a bed of [[activated carbon]] beads to adsorb [[volatile organic compound]]s (VOCs) from the [[exhaust gas]]. Evolving from the previous fixed-bed and carbon rotor concentrators, the FBC system forces the VOC-laden air through several perforated steel trays, increasing the velocity of the air and allowing the sub-millimeter carbon beads to fluidize, or behave as if suspended in a liquid. This increases the surface area of the carbon-gas interaction, making it more effective at capturing VOCs.
==Components== [[File:FBC-Solidworks.png|thumb|A 3-D design of the fluidized bed concentrator in Solidworks.]] The '''fluidized bed concentrator''' consists of five primary components: *[[Adsorption]] tower *[[Desorption]] tower *[[Thermal oxidizer]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tksindustrial.com/thermal-oxidizer|title=Thermal Oxidizer and Use with Fluidized Bed Concentrators|accessdate=30 November 2016}}</ref> *Carbon transport system *Process fans: Inlet [[adsorption|Adsorber]], Inlet Desorber, Outlet Oxidizer to Stack
==How it works== [[File:FBC Flow Schematic.png|thumb|left|400px|A flow schematic of process gas in the Fluidized Bed Concentrator system.]] Industrial Processes requiring ventilation, including paint booths,<ref>{{cite web|title=Toyota named Low-Carbon Auto Manufacturing of the Year|url=http://diversityandcommerce.biz/cocacola-enterprises-ford-toyota-named-as-low-carbon-champions-p3783-179.htm|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> printing, and chemical production, exhaust the ventilated air to the '''fluidized bed concentrator''' (FBC) at room temperature.<ref>{{cite web|title=VOC Emissions from Industrial Painting Processes|url=http://www.metalfinishing.com/view/2721/voc-emissions-from-industrial-painting-processes-as-a-source-of-fuel-cell-energy/|publisher=Metal Finishing|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> The air first passes into the Adsorption tower, where it moves through six perforated trays of clean carbon beads. The 0.7mm [[Bead activated carbon (BAC)]] fluidizes in the trays and captures the VOCs as they intermix.
The saturated carbon beads are passed from the Adsorber tower to the Desorber tower, where the beads are heated to 350 °F and the VOCs are released. Typically the Adsorber tower is many times larger than the Desorber tower, leading to an air volume reduction and an increase in VOC concentration. The ratio of Adsorber size to Desorber size is called the Concentration Ratio, and ranges from 10:1 to 100:1.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ford Environmental VOC Emissions|url=http://corporate.ford.com/microsites/sustainability-report-2013-14/environment-operations-facility|publisher=Ford|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref>
The concentrated VOC gas stream is sent from the Desorb tower to a [http://tksindustrial.com/thermal-oxidizer thermal oxidizer], where the organic compounds are heated to 1400 °F and oxidized, or broken down into Carbon Dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>), Water (H<sub>2</sub>0), and by-products. In some cases, small amounts of Carbon Monoxide (CO), Nitrogen Oxide (NO<sub>X</sub>), and other gases are produced.
==Emissions and energy usage== [[File:Honda Alabama Wins Air Quality Award.jpg|thumb|Members of the Honda Alabama Environmental Air Quality team are honored for their efforts to reduce CO<sub>2</sub> and NO<sub>x</sub> emissions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hondaalabama.com/article/hma-honored-as-air-conservationist-of-the-year|title=HMA Honored As Air Conservationist of the Year|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref>]] The primary advantage of the FBC over traditional rotor concentrators lies in its ability to achieve any concentration ratio up to the [[lower explosive limit]] (LEL). This allows Honda Alabama's paint shop to switch from oxidizing 100,000 CFM of VOCs in a Regenerative Thermal Oxidizer (RTO),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tksindustrial.com/regenerative-thermal-oxidizer|title=Regenerative Thermal Oxidizer Product Details|accessdate=10 January 2017}}</ref> to oxidizing only 1,500 CFM of VOCs in a small thermal oxidizer, at a much higher concentration. Reducing the volume of air to be oxidized from 100,000 CFM to 1,500 CFM (66:1 concentration ratio), allows for a much lower energy usage and consequently, fewer CO<sub>2</sub> and NO<sub>X</sub> emissions.
{{quotation | "Despite an increase in Line 2 production, Honda is realizing a reduction in plant VOC emissions of nearly 60 metric tons annually as a result of the installation of the FBC system. Also, the new [FBC] system uses approximately 20% of the energy of an RTO system." - Honda Manufacturing of Alabama}}
==Industries served== [[File:Fluidized Bed Concentrator.jpg|thumb|The Adsorber tower and stack of a Fluidized Bed Concentrator.]] *[[Paint Finishing]] **[[Automotive]] **[[Aerospace]] **[[Heavy Machinery]] **[[Transportation]] *[[Printing]] *[[Chemical production]] *[[Semiconductor]] *[[Food Processing]]
==Known suppliers== [[File:FBC-CFD.png|thumb|A computational fluid dynamics (CFD) model for airflow inside a FBC Adsorber tower. {{Infobox company| |name = G. Peignot et Fils |logo = Logo-g-peignot-et-fils.png |type = [[Kommanditgesellschaft]] |genre = |foundation = 1898 |founder = Pierre Leclerc, Gustave Peignot |defunct = 1919 |location = [[Paris]], [[France]] |key_people = Georges Peignot |industry = [[Type foundry]] |num_employees = |revenue = |homepage = }} '''G. Peignot et Fils foundry''' (Fonderie G. Peignot et Fils) was a French [[type foundry|typographic foundry]], established in 1898 and closed down between 1919 and 1923 after a merger to become [[Deberny & Peignot|Deberny & Peignot foundry]]. Led by [[Georges Peignot]] (1872–1915), G. Peignot & Fils was a prestigious French typographic foundry, an "elite house",<ref>{{cite journal | authorlink = Louis Barthou | title = Lettres à un jeune français. XXV. La contagion sublime | journal = Les Annales | volume = | issue = 1727 | pages = | date = July 1916 | language = french}}</ref> according to [[Louis Barthou]], former French Prime Minister.
== History == G. Peignot et Fils is founded in 1898 in [[Paris]], after absorption of the '''Veuve Routier et Peignot''' foundry (established in 1867), itself heir of the foundry "Veuve Routier" (established in 1865) and foundry of Pierre Leclerc (established in 1842).
=== Foundry of Pierre Leclerc (1842) === In 1842, Pierre Leclerc, a craftsman, creates a [[Letter-spacing|fixed spaces]] foundry (hand-set metal type to achieve letter-spacing) in Paris. ''"He can be considered as the genuine creator of the fixed spaces industry"'', says the magazine ''La fonderie typographique'' in 1899.<ref>{{cite journal | authorlink = | title = Gustave Peignot | journal = La fonderie typographique | volume = | issue = 7 | pages = | date = 1899 | language = french}}</ref> These fixed spaces between words and lines, margins, etc., require great precision. He invents a new process, instead of cutting fixed spaces, pouring them into molds, which increases accuracy. In 1856, after his death,<ref name="Tuleu">{{Citation | last1 = Tuleu | first1 = Jane | title = Souvenirs de famille | place = Paris | publisher = Deberny |pages = 77 | date = 1915 | isbn = | language = french}}</ref> the company management is entrusted to a friend of his widow, Clémentine Dupont de Vieux Pont (wife Peignot, 1815-1897). She then settles beside her his son, Gustave Peignot (1839-1899), engineer of [[Arts et Métiers ParisTech|Arts et Métiers school]].<ref name="froissart">{{Citation | last1 = Froissart | first1 = Jean-Luc | title = L’or, l’âme et les cendres du plomb. L'épopée des Peignot, 1815-1983 | place = Paris | publisher = librairie Tekhnê |pages = | date = 2004 | isbn = 2-9522836-0-5 | language = french}}</ref>
=== Veuve Routier (1865) and Veuve Routier et G. Peignot (1867) foundries=== In 1865, the foundry of Pierre Leclerc is sold by auction to Peignot. The new company is called "Veuve Routier" (''Widow Routier''), which is the name of the lessor having made possible the purchase by Gustave Peignot. In 1867, Gustave Peignot and the lessor merge in a company which takes the name of "Veuve Routier et Peignot."
In 1869 the company moved to Boulevard de Montrouge (now boulevard Edgar-Quinet), at no. 66-68, where a building is constructed (upstairs for the family, ground for the plant).<ref name="Tuleu" /> In 1875, the debt to the Veuve Routier is cleared, and Gustave Peignot becomes sole owner of the company and the building. [[File:1883-g-peignot-fonderie-publicite.png|thumb|600 px|Advertisement for G. Peignot foundry published in ''L'imprimerie'' magazine, in 1883]]
From 1875 to 1898, Gustave Peignot continues to make great profits with fixed spaces production, not amputated this time by refunds to the Veuve Routier. ''"In this lead will Thou find gold"'', used to say his mother.<ref name="froissart" /> At this time, Gustave Peignot becomes first President of the Chambre syndicale des maîtres fondeurs typographes (trade association of type foundry masters). He marries Marie Laporte, and is a father of 8 children.
=== G. Peignot et Fils Foundry (1898)=== In 1898, Gustave Peignot distributes to his children an equal parts of stocks and appoints Georges Peignot, his second son, as co-manager.<ref name="Tuleu" /> The company's name changes for "G. Peignot & Fils" (''G. Peignot & Sons''). He dies in 1899.
Georges Peignot continues the production of fixed spaces, causing significant growth in sales, and launches studies for new [[typeface]]s. The quality of fonts puts foundry G. Peignot et Fils at the forefront. In 12 years, Georges Peignot creates many typefaces: [[Grasset (typeface)|Grasset]], [[Auriol (typeface)|Auriol]], [[Cochin (typeface)|Cochin]], [[Garamond (typeface)|Garamond-Peignot]], [[Bellery-Desfontaines (typeface)|Bellery-Desfontaines]], [[Naudin (typeface)|Naudin]], [[Guy-Arnoux (typeface)|Guy-Arnoux]]. He also publishes a ''Specimen'', great typefaces catalog (still highly sought, 600 pages, 2 volumes).
In 1904, to address growth of sales, G. Peignot et Fils built a new plant at the corner of [[Rue Cabanis (Paris)|Cabanis]] and [[Rue Ferrus (Paris)|Ferrus]] streets. In 1911-1912, Georges Peignot sends in South America his two young brothers, Lucien and Rémy, looking for distributors. The company is at its peak.
But war brakes out in 1914. Volunteer for the front, Adjudant Georges Peignot is killed by a bullet to the forehead at the head of his section, Sept. 28, 1915, near Givenchy.<ref name="froissart">{{Citation | last1 = Froissart | first1 = Jean-Luc | title = L’or, l’âme et les cendres du plomb. L'épopée des Peignot, 1815-1983 | place = Paris | publisher = librairie Tekhnê |pages = | date = 2004 | isbn = 2-9522836-0-5 | language = french}}</ref> His four brothers also die.
The legacy of Georges Peignot is taken hostage by infighting: in 1919, his own mother, Marie Laporte-Peignot, requires its children or their widows the payment of a substantial sum (1 million of French francs, equivalent of USD [2015] 1,4 million) in the form of a capital increase<ref name="froissart" /> to its competitor Deberny (founded by [[Honoré de Balzac|Balzac]] in 1826), owned by Charles Tuleu (heir of Alexandre de Berny and husband of Jane Peignot-Tuleu). In 1923, G. Peignot et Fils foundry disappears, victim of the merger between Deberny foundry (2.6 million, including the 1 million Peignot subsidy) and G. Peignot & Fils foundry (4.1 million). The new company's name relegates Peignot's name in background: the new entity is indeed called "[[Deberny et Peignot]]" and commonly called "Deberny". Against all logic (the manager is usually chosen by the majority shareholder), the manager of the small Deberny foundry, Robert Girard, under whom the old foundry Deberny had collapsed,<ref name="froissart" /> takes the reins of the new entity.
In 1922, the Commission de l’enseignement et des beaux-arts (governmental ''Commission for education and fine arts'') suggests honoring the story of Peignot: it transports the awls of the foundry in the building of the Imprimerie nationale (Government printing office), near [[Rue Gutenberg (Paris)|Gutenberg street]] in [[Paris]]. And it proposes that the continuation of this street would be baptized "[[Rue des Quatre-Frères-Peignot (Paris)|rue des Quatre-Frères-Peignot]]" (''Four-brothers-Peignot street'') in memory of Georges, André, Lucien and Rémy who died between September, 1914 and June, 1916, snatched by the World War I.
== Typographical creations == G. Peignot & Fils foundry is the heart of important typographic creations, including: * the [[Grasset (typeface)|Grasset]] (drawing with reed pen : [[Eugène Grasset]], 1898-1901) ; * the [[Auriol (typeface)|Française-légère]], the [[Auriol (typeface)|Française-allongée]], the [[Auriol (typeface)|Auriol-labeur]], the [[Auriol (typeface)|Auriol-champlevé]], and the [[Auriol (typeface)|Robur]] (drawing with brush : [[George Auriol]], 1902-1907) ; * the [[Bellery-Desfontaines (typeface)|Bellery-Desfontaines-large]] et le [[Bellery-Desfontaines (typeface)|Bellery-Desfontaines-étroit]] (drawing : [[Henri Bellery-Desfontaines]], 1910-1912) ; * the [[Polyphème (typeface)|Polyphème]] (bold) et le [[Cyclopéen (typeface)|Cyclopéen]] (light) (anonymous creation, 1910) ; * the [[Cochin (typeface)|Cochin]] book and italic, the [[Nicolas-Cochin (typeface)|Nicolas-Cochin]] book and italic, engraved by [[Charles Malin]], the [[Moreau-le-Jeune (typeface)|Moreau-le-Jeune]], the [[Fournier-le-Jeune (typeface)|Fournier-le-Jeune]], the vignettes et ornaments [[Fournier (typeface)|Fournier]] (drawing : P. Roy et A. Marty) ; * the [[Garamond (typeface)|Garamond]] book and italic (engraved by Henri Parmentier, from prints on rag paper of the genuine Garamond typeface, under careful control of [[Georges Peignot]] (1912-1914) ; launched in 1926) ; * the [[Naudin (typeface)|Naudin]] book, italic and champlevé (drawing : [[Bernard Naudin]], 1909-1914 ; launched in 1924) ; * the [[Guy-Arnoux (typeface)|Guy-Arnoux capitales]] (drawing : [[Guy Arnoux]], 1914).

{{mdy|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Hirotaka Takeuchi | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Hirotaka Takeuchi - World Economic Forum Annual Meeting Davos 2009.jpg | image_size = | alt = Hirotaka Takeuchi | caption = At the 2009 World Economic Forum, Davos | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1946|10|16|df=y}} {{cite web|url=http://www.ngmf.com/ngmf2013/speakers22.html |page=|title= Speaker Profile|publisher=15th Nikkei Global Management Forum|accessdate=8 November 2017}} | birth_place = | disappeared_date = | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = [[Japanese-American]] | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = [[International Christian University]]
[[University of California, Berkeley]] | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = Influencing business practices worldwide | notable_works = | style = | influences = | influenced = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | religion = | denomination = | criminal_charge = | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} {{Nihongo|'''Hirotaka Takeuchi'''|竹内 弘高|Takeuchi Hirotaka}} is a Professor of Management Practice in the Strategy Unit at [[Harvard Business School]]. {{cite web|url=http://www.hbs.edu/faculty/Pages/profile.aspx?facId=6563|page=|title= Hirotaka Takeuchi - Professor of Management Practice |publisher=Harvard Business School|accessdate=8 November 2017}} He co-authored ''The New New Product Development Game'' which influenced the development of the [[Scrum (development)|Scrum framework]].{{cite book | first = Jeff| last = Sutherland| authorlink = | author2 = | year = | month = | title = Scrum: The Art of Doing Twice the Work in Half the Time| chapter = | editor = | others = | edition = | pages = 32-33| publisher = Random House Business Books| location = | isbn = 9781847941107| url = }} ==Biography== Takeuchi was born in 1946 and gained a B.A. from [[International Christian University]] in [[Tokyo]], and an M.B.A. and Ph.D. from the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. His early non-academic career included work at [[McCann-Erickson]] in Tokyo and San Francisco and at [[McKinsey & Company]] in Tokyo. From 1976 to 1983 Takeuchi had his first faculty position at Harvard Business School, as an assistant professor in the Marketing Unit. He moved to [[Hitotsubashi University]] in Tokyo in 1983, becoming a professor in 1987. In another spell at Harvard Business School from 1995 to 1996, Takeuchi served as a visiting professor in the Advanced Management Program. In 1998 Takeuchi became the founding dean of Hitotsubashi University's business school, the Graduate School of International Corporate Strategy. 2010 saw Takeuchi appointed to the position of Professor Emeritus at that university and in the same year he was additionally appointed as a professor at Harvard Business School.{{cite web|url=https://www.mitsui.com/jp/en/company/outline/officer/1219499_7041.html|title=Director - Hirotaka Takeuchi |publisher=Mitsui|accessdate=8 November 2017}} Takeuchi has written or co-authored numerous articles for the [[Harvard Business Review]].{{cite web|url=https://hbr.org/search?term=hirotaka+takeuchi|title=Search : Hirotaka Takeuchi |publisher=Harvard Business Review|accessdate=8 November 2017}} He has served on the planning board of the [[World Economic Forum]]{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=2529243&capId=52322137&previousCapId=91829&previousTitle=Mitsui%20%26%20Co.%2C%20Ltd.|title=Executive Profile - Hirotaka Takeuchi Ph.D. |publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=8 November 2017}} and is an external director at [[Mitsui|Mitsui & Co.]] and an outside director at Daiwa Securities Group Inc.{{cite web|url=http://www.daiwa-grp.jp/english/corporate/corporate_01.html|title=Daiwa Securities Group Inc. - Corporate Profile |publisher=Daiwa Securities|accessdate=8 November 2017}} == The New New Product Development Game == Takeuchi collaborated on a number of articles with [[Ikujiro Nonaka]] (野中 郁次郎), a colleague at Hitotsubashi University, including the 1986 Harvard Business Review article ''The New New Product Development Game'', in which they emphasised speed and flexibility for [[new product development]].{{cite journal | last = Takeuchi | first = H | last2 = Nonaka | first2 = I | date = 1986 | title = The New New Product Development Game | url = | journal = Harvard Business Review | volume = | issue = January/February | pages = 285-305 | doi = | access-date = }} The article looked at practices in a number of successful manufacturing companies such as [[Fuji-Xerox]], [[Honda]], [[3M]] and [[Toyota]]. The authors drew attention to the practise in those companies of having an overlapping development process ('like [[Sashimi]]'), rather than the older sequential approach. They likened it to the game of [[Rugby Union]], where a team 'tries to go the distance as a unit, passing the ball back and forth' and where a team may employ different tactics to make the best use of its talents. The authors found that teams in the most successful companies they examined exhibited the following conditions:{{cite book | first = Jeff| last = Sutherland| authorlink = | author2 = | year = | month = | title = Scrum: The Art of Doing Twice the Work in Half the Time| chapter = | editor = | others = | edition = | pages = 44| publisher = Random House Business Books| location = | isbn = 9781847941107| url = }}
  • Autonomy - being self-organising and empowered to make decisions over how to do the work
  • Cross-fertilization - having within the teams all the skills needed to complete the task
  • Self-Transcendence - elevating their goals and pushing beyond the normally accepted limit; challenging the status quo
    • The article attracted attention when it was published but its significance for software development was born seven years later when a team at Easel Corporation led by [[Jeff Sutherland]] alighted on the article and spotted the opportunity it offered to achieve their goal of delivering software on schedule and under budget. Sutherland went on to develop the concept in conjunction with [[Ken Schwaber]] as the [[Scrum (development)|Scrum framework]]{{cite web|url=https://www.scruminc.com/takeuchi-and-nonaka-roots-of-scrum/|title=Takeuchi and Nonaka: The Roots of Scrum |publisher=scrum.inc|accessdate=8 November 2017}}, an [[agile software development]] technique now used across the globe.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/stevedenning/2011/04/29/scrum-is-a-major-management-discovery/#2551b1d07782|title=Scrum is a Major Management Discovery|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=8 November 2017}} == The Nonaka-Takeuchi model of accumulation of knowledge == Takeuchi's colleague Ikujiro Nonaka wrote an article ''The Knowledge-Creating Company'' in the Harvard Business Review, 1991. {{cite journal | last = Nonaka | first = I | date = 1991 | title = The Knowledge-Creating Company | url = https://hbr.org/2007/07/the-knowledge-creating-company | journal = Harvard Business Review | volume = | issue = November/December | pages = | doi = | access-date = 8 November 2017 }} It explored two types of knowledge, namely [[tacit knowledge]] which is that learned by experience and communicated indirectly, and [[explicit knowledge]], which is that recorded in documentation, manuals and procedures. Nonaka wrote that Japanese companies viewed knowledge as primarily tacit but had mastered converting tacit to explicit and back again (the 'spiral of knowledge'). In 1995 Nonaka and Takeuchi co-authored a book which expanded on the subject and brought it to a wider audience{{cite web |url=https://www.thefreelibrary.com/Ikujiro+Nonaka+%3a+Knowledge+creation.-a085608620 |page= |title= The Free Library - Ikujiro Nonaka : Knowledge creation. |publisher= Farlex inc. |accessdate=8 November 2017 }}: ''The Knowledge-Creating Company : How Japanese Companies Create the Dynamics of Innovation''{{cite book |ref=harv |last=Nonaka |first=Ikujiro |author-link=Ikujiro Nonaka |last2=Takeuchi |first2=Hirotaka |author2-link= |year=1995 |title=The Knowledge-Creating Company: how Japanese companies create the dynamics of innovation |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=New York |pages= 284 |isbn=9780195092691|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B-qxrPaU1-MC }}. The authors described the methods used in successful Japanese companies to create new knowledge and use it to produce successful products. They called this 'organizational knowledge creation' - an ability to 'create new knowledge, disseminate it throughout the organization and embody it in products, services and systems'. The book was named as Best Book of the Year in Business and Management, 1996 by the [[Association of American Publishers]]. ==Selected bibliography== *{{Citation | last=Takeuchi | first=Hirotaka | author-link= | last2=Ikujiro | first2=Nonaka | author2-link=Ikujiro Nonaka | year=1995 | title=The knowledge creating company: how Japanese companies create the dynamics of innovation | publisher=Oxford University Press | location=New York | pages= 284 | isbn=978-0195092691 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=B-qxrPaU1-MC }} *{{Citation | last=Porter | first=Michael E. | author-link= | last2=Takeuchi | first2=Hirotaka | author2-link= | last3=Sakakibara| first3=Mariko | author3-link= | year=2000 | title=Can Japan Compete? | publisher= Palgrave Macmillan | location= | pages= | isbn= 978-0333786581 | url= https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=v875Js7t3uQC&dq=hirotaka+takeuchi+can+japan+compete&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwixrduUy7fXAhWFAMAKHWTDDQ8Q6AEIJjAA }} *{{Citation | last=Takeuchi | first=Hirotaka | year=2004 | title=Hirotaka on Knowledge Management | publisher= Wiley | location= | pages= | isbn= 978-0470820742 | url= https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=VJ-GQgAACAAJ&dq=hirotaka+takeuchi&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj48frhvLfXAhVH6KQKHcifD9oQ6AEIKTAA }} *{{Citation | last=Takeuchi | first=Hirotaka | author-link= | last2=Shimizu| first2=Norihiko | author2-link= | last3=Osono | first3=Emi | author3-link= | year=2008 | title=Extreme Toyota: Radical Contradictions That Drive Success at the World's Best Manufacturer | publisher=John Wiley & Sons Ltd | location= | pages= | isbn= | url= }} *{{Citation | last=Takeuchi | first=Hirotaka | author-link= | last2=Kase| first2=Kimeo | author2-link= | last3=von Krogh| first3=Georg | author3-link= | last4=Cantón| first4=César González | author4-link= | year=2013 | title=Towards Organizational Knowledge: The Pioneering Work of Ikujiro Nonaka | publisher= Palgrave Macmillan | location= | pages= | isbn= 978-1137024954 | url= https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=2R4hAQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=,+Towards+Organizational+Knowledge:+The+Pioneering+Work+of+Ikujiro+Nonaka&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj1u6Pdy7fXAhUkDMAKHTILAOYQ6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q=%2C%20Towards%20Organizational%20Knowledge%3A%20The%20Pioneering%20Work%20of%20Ikujiro%20Nonaka&f=false }} ==See also== [[Hirotaka]] - a Japanese masculine given name. {{Infobox person | name = Jaime Bonilla Valdez | image = | caption = | birthname = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1950|6|9}} | birth_place = [[Tijuana]], [[Baja California]], Mexico | age = | death_date = | death_place = | education = | occupation = Senator, deputy | party = [[Labor_Party_(Mexico)|PT]] (?–2014)
[[National_Regeneration_Movement|MRN]] (2014–present) | alias = | gender = | status = | title = | family = | spouse = | children = | relatives = | ethnicity = | religion = | salary = | networth = | credits = | agent = | URL = http://jaimebonilla.com/ }} '''Jaime Bonilla Valdez''' (born 9 June 1950) is a [[Mexicans|Mexican]] politician and businessman affiliated with the [[National Regeneration Movement]] (formerly of the [[Labor Party (Mexico)|Labor Party]]) who will serve as a [[Senate of the Republic (Mexico)|senator]] representing [[Baja California]] in the [[LXIV Legislature of the Mexican Congress|LXIV Legislature]] of the Mexican Congress. He had previously been a proportional representation federal deputy from the state to the [[LXII Legislature of the Mexican Congress|LXII Legislature]].{{cite web|title=Perfil del legislador|url=http://sil.gobernacion.gob.mx/Librerias/pp_PerfilLegislador.php?SID=&Referencia=9217023|publisher=Legislative Information System|accessdate=15 November 2013}} ==Life== Bonilla was born in Tijuana and obtained his degree in business administration from the [[UNAM]] in 1983. He worked in a variety of companies, including Electrol de México, CONESA, and COVIMEX de México.{{r|sil}} Between 1982 and 1985, he directed the [[Potros de Tijuana]] baseball club, which played in the [[Liga Mexicana del Pacífico]].{{cite news|url=http://www.elfinanciero.com.mx/nacional/jaime-bonilla-sedujo-a-amlo-pero-dividio-a-morena-en-bc|date=29 December 2016|title=Jaime Bonilla sedujo a AMLO, pero dividió a Morena en BC|first=Rivelino|last=Rueda|work=El Financiero|language=Spanish|accessdate=10 August 2018}} In 1984, he became the director general and a columnist of the ''Diario de Baja California'' newspaper, which began a career in media ownership for Bonilla. Through his company PSN (originally an acronym for Pacific Spanish Network, now Primer Sistema de Noticias), he directly operates [[XESS-AM]] 620 and [[XESDD-AM]] 1030 in Tijuana. He also owned [[XHENB-TV]] channel 29 in [[Ensenada, Baja California|Ensenada]], now a cable-only outlet, and his company Media Sports de México holds the concessions for two radio stations operated under brokerage agreements by American programmers, [[XEPE-AM]] 1700 and [[XHPRS-FM]] 105.7. Bonilla also acquired cable systems in Ensenada and [[Tecate]]. Bonilla also owned radio station [[KURS]] 1040 in San Diego through his company Quetzal Bilingual Communications; the station was sold in 2016 for $900,000.{{cite news|url=http://www.insideradio.com/features/deal_digest/deal-digest---november/article_ba52b346-b146-11e6-b43e-cf236de8b4fe.html|work=Inside Radio|title=Deal Digest - November 23, 2016|date=23 November 2016|accessdate=10 August 2018}} In 2000, Bonilla, then a dual citizen of Mexico and the United States, joined the board of the Otay Water District in Otay Mesa, California. While in the US, he was a donor to [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] causes and even was on the California finance committee for [[John McCain presidential campaign, 2008|John McCain's 2008 presidential campaign]].{{cite news|url=https://www.razon.com.mx/republicano-que-financio-a-mccain-ya-es-diputado-del-pt/|work=La Razón|first=Jorge|last=González|title=Republicano que financió a McCain ya es diputado del PT|date=19 September 2012|accessdate=10 August 2018|language=Spanish}} In March 2012, he announced his resignation from the water board in order to run for federal deputy and simultaneously join the 2012 presidential campaign of [[Andrés Manuel López Obrador]].{{cite news|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/environment/sdut-otays-bonilla-resigns-high-profile-posts-mexico-2012mar27-story.html|work=San Diego Union-Tribune|title=Otay's Bonilla resigns for high-profile posts in Mexico|first=Sandra|last=Dibble|accessdate=10 August 2018|date=27 March 2012}} At the same time, he renounced his dual citizenship,{{r|ef}} a move necessary to meet the constitutional requirements to run for office.{{cite web|url=https://www.eleconomista.com.mx/opinion/Doble-nacionalidad-20180603-0069.html|title=Doble nacionalidad|first=Marco Antonio|last=Baños|work=El Economista|date=3 June 2018|language=Spanish|accessdate=6 September 2018}} He became a proportional representation deputy on the [[Labor Party (Mexico)|PT]] list, during which time he served as the president of the Northern Border Matters Commission and was the state campaign coordinator for the PT in the 2013 Baja California state elections.{{r|sil}} Bonilla left the post in 2014 in order to become the state party director for the then-new Morena party.{{r|ef}} His relationship with López Obrador remained close; in 2016, Bonilla invited him to his [[Petco Park]] suite for the [[2016 Major League Baseball All-Star Game]].{{r|ef}} Party members and leaders say that in Bonilla's media holdings, López Obrador saw a "gold mine" to gain media exposure in Baja California.{{r|ef}} On 31 January 2018, López Obrador announced that Bonilla would be the primary Senate candidate in Baja California for the [[Juntos Haremos Historia]] coalition, forming a ticket with [[Alejandra León Gastélum]].{{cite news|url=http://blancoynegro.mx/~wynegr0/politica-y-policiaca/16985-va-jaime-bonilla-por-la-candidatura-al-senado.html|work=Blanco y Negro|date=31 January 2018|first=Conrado|last=Osuna Murillo|title=Va Jaime Bonilla por la candidatura al Senado|language=Spanish|accessdate=10 August 2018}} The Juntos Haremos Historia ticket took first place in the election, securing both candidates seats in the Senate. However, Bonilla has stated that he will only remain in office three months and will then become the state development coordinator in Baja California.{{cite news|url=http://www.lacronica.com/EdicionEnLinea/Notas/Noticias/13072018/1356617-Jaime-Bonilla-solo-sera-Senador-por-BC-durante-tres-meses.html|work=La Crónica|first=Glenn|last=Sánchez|date=13 July 2018|title=Jaime Bonilla solo será Senador por BC durante tres meses|accessdate=10 August 2018|language=Spanish}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bonilla Valdez, Jaime}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Tijuana]] [[Category:Politicians from Baja California]] [[Category:Mexican businesspeople]] [[Category:Members of the Chamber of Deputies (Mexico)]] [[Category:Labor Party (Mexico) politicians]] [[Category:National Regeneration Movement politicians]] [[Category:21st-century Mexican politicians]]

{{Infobox person |name = James Ferragamo |image = |caption = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1971|11|07|df=y}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.lapietradialogues.org/dialogues_bio.php?cat=7&id=27&bio=88|title=James Ferragamo|first=|last=|quote=|publisher=[[Lapietra dialogues]]|date=}} |birth_place = [[Florence]], [[Italy]] |death_date = |death_place = |residence = |nationality = Italian |alma_mater = [[New York University Stern School of Business|New York University]] |relatives = [[Salvatore Ferragamo]]
(grandfather) |parents = Ferruccio Ferragamo
Amanda Peat |known_for = Women's and Men's Shoes and Leather goods Division Director of [[Salvatore Ferragamo|Ferragamo]] |occupation = Businessman }} '''James Ferragamo''' ( born on November 7, 1971) is a businessman from Italy and a member of family of [[Salvatore Ferragamo|Ferragamo]]. Now he is the Men's and Women’s Leather Product Director for the [[Salvatore Ferragamo S.p.A.]]. ==Biography== James is the twin son of Ferruccio Ferragamo, who is [[Chairman]] of Salvatore Ferragamo S.p.A, and his grandfather [[Salvatore Ferragamo]] is the founder of the brand. He is a graduate of [[New York University Stern School of Business]]. Now he is the Women's and Men's Shoes and Leather goods Division Director for [[Salvatore Ferragamo S.p.A.]]. ==Family== *[[Salvatore Ferragamo]]: James' grandfather, the founder of [[Salvatore Ferragamo S.p.A.]] ==References== {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ferragamo, James}} [[Category:1971 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Italian fashion designers]] [[Category:Italian businesspeople]] [[Category:Italian billionaires]] [[Category:New York University alumni]] [[Category:Twin people from Italy]] [[Category:People from Florence]] {{Italy-business-bio-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=January 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox person | image = File:Indrajit Solomon Arulampalam.jpg | name = Jitto Arulampalam | caption = Jitto Arulampalam | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Jaffna]], Sri Lanka | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Australian | known_for = | alma_mater = [[Casuarina Senior College]]([[Darwin, Northern Territory]], Australia), [[Curtin University]]([[Perth]], [[Western Australia]]) and [[Australian Institute of Company Directors]] | occupation = '''Chairman''' of,
Progen Pharmaceuticals Limited

'''Executive chairman''' of,
[[Lanka Graphite Limited]]

'''Chairman(formerly)''' of,
Euro Petroleum Limited
&
Great Western Exploration Limited
&
Fortis Mining Limited
&
Medivision Limited | residence = [[Melbourne]], Australia | spouse = | website = [http://www.progen-pharma.com Progen Pharmaceuticals Limited] | footnotes = }} '''Indrajit Solomon Arulampalam''' (known as '''''Jitto Arulampalam''''') is an Australian businessman of [[Sri Lankan Tamil]] origin. He is the current Chairman of Progen Pharmaceuticals Limited and the Executive Chairman of [[Lanka Graphite Limited]] and was the Chairman of Euro Petroleum Limited, Great Western Exploration Limited, Fortis Mining Limited and Medivision Limited.{{cite web|url=http://www.progen-pharma.com/company/board.aspx |title=Board of Directors |publisher=Progen Pharmaceuticals Limited |accessdate=7 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141216163043/http://www.progen-pharma.com/company/board.aspx |archivedate=16 December 2014 |df= }}{{cite web | url= https://www.bloomberg.com/profiles/people/16316453-indrajit-solomon-arulampalam| title=Indrajit "Jitto" Arulampalam| publisher= [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|accessdate=7 November 2014}}{{cite web | url= http://www.smh.com.au/business/nab-joins-muddled-echo-party-20120306-1uidp.html| title=NAB joins muddled Echo party| work= [[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|accessdate=7 November 2014}}{{cite web | url= http://www.kazakhpotash.com/kazakhstan_potash_corporation_08072011.html| title=Fortis float opens doors| date= 8 July 2011| publisher= [[The Australian Financial Review]](Republished at www.kazakhpotash.com)|accessdate=7 November 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://in.reuters.com/finance/stocks/PGL.AX/key-developments/article/2878244 |title=Progen Pharmaceuticals Ltd appoints Jitto Arulampalam as chairman |date=29 November 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141106235320/http://in.reuters.com/finance/stocks/PGL.AX/key-developments/article/2878244 |archivedate= 6 November 2014 |df= }}{{cite web | url=http://www.computerworld.com.au/tag/jitto-arulampalam/news| title=Jitto Arulampalam – News, Features, and Slideshows| date= 29 November 2013 | work= [[Computerworld]]|accessdate=7 November 2014}}{{cite web | url=http://www.theage.com.au/business/strange-times-and-capital-ideas-20090305-8q47.html| title=Strange times and capital ideas| date=6 March 2009| work= [[The Age]]|accessdate=7 November 2014}}{{cite web | url=http://in.reuters.com/finance/stocks/officerProfile?symbol=PGLA.PK&officerId=2413895| title=Arulampalam, Indrajit|accessdate=7 November 2014}}{{cite web | url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=51760222&ticker=PGL:AU| title=Indrajit Solomon Arulampalam| date=4 November 2014| work= [[Bloomberg BusinessWeek]]|accessdate=7 November 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://newmaterialsnews.com/graphene-news/lanka-graphite-starts-trading-on-asx-targets-graphene-market |title=Lanka Graphite starts trading on ASX, targets graphene market |date=10 August 2015 |publisher=News Materials News |accessdate=3 October 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151004080940/http://newmaterialsnews.com/graphene-news/lanka-graphite-starts-trading-on-asx-targets-graphene-market |archivedate= 4 October 2015 |df= }} He is a board member of Mekong Mining Ltd and Newsnet Itn Ltd. [[Australian Financial Review]] MIS Magazine 2006 recognised him as one of the ''Top 25 global rising stars''. ==Education== Jitto did his schooling at [[Casuarina Senior College|Casuarina High School]] and then completed his [[Bachelor of Business Administration]] at [[Curtin University]]. He also attended at [[Australian Institute of Company Directors]].{{cite web | url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/943502/000110465913054331/a13-16602_3ex99d1.htm| title=Progen Pharmaceuticals:Board and Senior Management Changes| date=12 July 2013| publisher= [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]|accessdate=7 November 2014}} ==Career== He is based in [[Melbourne]] with over two decades experience in [[corporate restructuring]], capital raising, listing and running of public companies on the [[Australian Securities Exchange|ASX]]. Jitto's first job was in accounting and then shifted into banking; he was with [[Westpac Banking Corporation]] for more than eight years in various senior managerial positions. Jitto is the co-founder of Fortis Mining Ltd., a company dedicated to [[potash]] mining and exploration; the company is listed at [[Australian Securities Exchange]]. He was credited for masterminding the Fortis's acquisition of high quality potash assets in [[Kazakhstan]]. The deal paved the way for the company to be awarded "[[IPO]] of the Year 2011".{{cite web | url=http://video.cnbc.com/gallery/?video=3000049441| title=Fortis Mining for Success in Kazakhstan | date=5 October 2011| publisher= [[CNBC]]|accessdate=8 November 2014}} ==Social activities== Jitto visited war-ravaged [[Jaffna]] as the co-sponsor of Murali Harmony Cup in 2014; OYOB where Jitto is the chairman jointly sponsored the Cup to develop and encourage school cricketers in Sri Lanka's rural areas, especially in the war-affected north and east, promoting community-building and cross-cultural friendships within Sri Lankan society.{{cite web| url=http://www.oyob.com.au/meet-your-team| title=JITTO ARULAMPALAM| publisher=OYOB| accessdate=8 November 2014| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108103229/http://www.oyob.com.au/meet-your-team/| archivedate=8 November 2014| df=}}{{cite web | url=http://www.thesundayleader.lk/2014/10/26/murali-harmony-cup| title=Murali Harmony Cup| date=26 October 2014| publisher= [[The Sunday Leader]]|accessdate=8 November 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://video.cnbc.com/gallery/?video=3000049441 Fortis Mining for Success in Kazakhstan]([[CNBC]] Video) * [http://www.island.lk/index.php?page_cat=article-details&page=article-details&code_title=163322 A pick of Sri Lankans who have enriched their new homeland – Australia] {{DEFAULTSORT:Arulampalam, Jitto}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Australian businesspeople]] [[Category:Curtin University alumni]] [[Category:Chief executives in the finance industry]] [[Category:Private equity and venture capital investors]] [[Category:Stock and commodity market managers]] [[Category:Financial advisors]] [[Category:Australian people of Sri Lankan Tamil descent]] [[Category:Sri Lankan Tamil businesspeople]] {{Australia-business-bio-stub}}
